claim.hypothesis: Covid-19 humor will be more aversive than humor on more benign topics.
claim.statement: Results showed that Covid-19 humor is associated with a mark of aversiveness, greater than for non-pandemic humor with differences in Aversiveness being found(+0.39,t=+2.26,p<.05) between Covid Verbal (M=0.87) and Non Covid Verbal (M=0.48)

data.source: web-based survey on LimeSurvey (https://limesurvey.org); Facebook pages posting entertaining contents (>10k followers); Coping Humor Scale (CHS) (Martin & Lefcourt, 1983) and Life Orientation Test – Revised (LOTR) (Scheier, Carver, & Bridges, 1994; Italian version: Giannini, Schuldberg, Di Fabio, & Gargaro, 2008) for personality measures (the use of humour in coping with stressful situations - CHS and dispositional optimism - LOTR)
data.unit_of_analysis: individual (native speakers of Italian (556 M, 1195 F), living in Italy (126 participants completed it from abroad), and aged above 18)
data.access_details: the authors state that the material used in the current study, as well as the dataset and the R script for the analyses, are available in the Open Science Framework repository (https://osf.io/gj52h/). There is no mention about restrictions and/or request process.
data.notes: Repeated item ratings per participant produced a crossed structure (Participants × Items × Province); reported effects derive from the final model selected with likelihood-ratio tests; Continuous predictors were z-standardized.

method.description: Covid and non-covid jokes were presented to the participants via a web-based LimeSurvey questionnaire. They rated each item’s aversiveness and completed measures of coping humor, dispositional optimism, and psychological distance to Covid-19. Linear Mixed Models with crossed random effects were used to test how humor type, demographics, personality, and psychological distance predicted aversiveness ratings
method.steps: 1. Extract internet jokes from humor hubs, (Facebook pages posting entertaining contents (>10k followers)), and humorous strips. Divide them into related to Covid-19 or not (NonCovid Verbal serve as baseline and included miscellaneous themes, generally softer and benign). 2. Divide Covid-19 humor further into three types: Covid Verbal (n=12), Covid Meme (n=6), and Covid Strip (n=6). 3. Create the survey using the jokes (ask participants to rate each humor item for funniness and aversiveness on two 7-point scales from 0 to 6).  4. Add demographics (Age, Gender, Provenance) questions, psychological distance questions (perceived risk of Covid-19 infection on 1–10 scale, social distance as number of known Covid-19 cases among friends/relatives). 5. Add personality measures: Coping Humor Scale (CHS) and Life Orientation Test – Revised (LOTR). 6. Recruit participants via social media, targeted Facebook ads, public communication, and email and present them with the survey. First, they will provide informed consent and demographics (Age, Gender and Provenance), then complete a section with psychological distance questions, the personality assessment, and then they will be asked to rate each item for funniness and aversiveness on two 7-point scales ranging from 0 (not at all funny/disturbing) to 6 (very funny/disturbing) 7. Calculate spatial distance as the geodesic distance (in kilometers) between the epicenter of the Italian outbreak (Codogno) and the municipality where each participant completed the questionnaire. 8. After collecting and cleaning the data, fit Linear Mixed Models in R with crossed random effects for Participants, Items, and Province, building four increasingly complex models for each outcome and comparing goodness of fit.
method.models: linear mixed models (crossed random effects for Participants, Items, and Province; hierarchical model comparison using likelihood ratio tests)
method.control_variables: Demographic factors (Age, Gender, and Education), Personality measures (CHS and LOTR scores), and Psychological Distance (Perceived risk, Spatial distance, and Social distance) on the two dependent variables (Funniness and Aversiveness)

results.summary: Covid-19 humor is associated with a greater aversiveness, than non-pandemic humor. Differences in Aversiveness (+0.39,t=+2.26,p<.05) between Covid Verbal (M=0.87) and Non Covid Verbal (M=0.48)

numerical_results.value: 0.39 difference in mean aversiveness (Covid Verbal M=0.87, NonCovid Verbal M=0.48)

metadata.original_paper_title: Funny but aversive: A large-scale survey on the emotional response to Covid-19 humor in the Italian population during the lockdown.
